top_comment.text:
THE AC/HEATER/FAN ISSUE IS SUCH A HUGE THING I TOOK FOR GRANTED---- and 
this is only withIN the usa~ so i was born & raised in houston, Texas- its 
HOT so we have ACs everywhere. and of course we have heaters for the 
"winter". Then i moved to Seattle, Washington (STILL IN THE USA) and i 
swear to all the fucking wack-a-moles on earth IT'S LIKE THEY HAVE NEVER 
HEARD OF AN AC. only stores, schools and rich people or actual houses have 
AC. of course its cold all year just about but soemtimes in winter I leave 
my heater for too long i almost suffocate so I wanna turn on the AC to 
balance it out but WE HAVE NONE. So i have to open the windows which is 
what everyeone here does~ but like in houston YOU DONT OPEN WINDOWS UNLESS 
IT'S SUMMER AND UR AC IS BROKEN OR SHITTY. and here the heaters are these 
weird box things almost to the floor compared to the AC/Heater vents 
upclose to the ceiling (<--we have in Houston)~
~ and another thing is ceiling fans and ceiling LIGHTS in apartments tend 
to not exist in many places in Washington... like u'll find them in the 
kitchen and bathroom~ maybe the dinning room if u have one- but in bedrooms 
and living room its like "hahahah who needs light? go buy a lamp". You're 
lucky if you find a place with a ceiling light in the bedrooms. and then 
ceiling fans~ it's hard to find apts in WA that have them- my apt has one 
but it only in the dining room... like wth i want one in my bedroom!
Atleast here in the USA we have it better than when I lived in El Salvador 
where we had no ac or heater in the house and only had holes in the walls 
for air ventilation. but yea--- even in the SAME COUNTRY things can be so 
different.﻿
top_comment.author: kimmicci

comments.text: +kimmicci How are you?

comments.text: +shadowsangheili  HOLA! :D lol
comments.author: kimmicci

So true!, When I went to Flordia from New Jersey Everywhere in Florida was 
all different, Some things I noticed
~Weather, In Florida I baked alive, while inNew Jersey The humidity hits

like only for 10 minutes, while in NJ It rains all day, and not just rain 
it pours heavily for a few days usually
~ In Florida a lot of stores are baige or brown very light colors, while in 
jersey stores or what ever color they want to be
~ A  thing About Nj is you have to pay to go to the beach, but they tend to 
be very clean and nicely kept while in Florida I noticed garbage everywhere 
and it was pretty dirty
~ Florida Keeps their highways and like gardens areas  very clean and 
trimmed while you come to jersey you see weeds and cattails growing 
everywhere  thats are like 6 feet tall xD
~Everyone seems to have a pool and central air, In New Jersey Central air 
is almost nonexisting in houses, Installing that heavy Ac in the summer, 
and burnign yourself on the oh so very hot heater ;____;

OMG, I could not agree more with you. I moved from Seattle to Sacramento

comments.author: Jessica Dodge

top_comment.text:
Korea's air condition/heating situation is ridiculous if not hillarious. 
 There's a national propaganda and brain washing going on to make people 
think airconditioning is bad and no heating toughen you up.  I remember 
when I was in middle school they were using a vintage furnace donated by 
Red Cross during Korean war.   And they would cut the heat little past 
noon, because the heat was supposed to last till end of class.  It's like a 
scene from Christmas Carol at Scrooge's Office. 

It's all bullshit for govt and public org/comp excuse to save money on 
Energy $$$$ without having to build more power plants.  

Has anyone heard of this mythical illness called "Aircon Sickness" outside 
Korea anyone?  Symptom is just a common cold.  Yet they label it "Aircon 
Sickness".  I smell conspiracy.

Even the "Fan Death".  I bet it was propagated by govt and media so that 
people will cutback on Electricity and allow Fan companies to make extra 
few cents off of that timer dial they put in.        ﻿
top_comment.author: Xentradi97

comments.text:
+Vixx Celacea Not so.  I live abroad not in Korea.  I lived in the US, 
Philippines and now Singapore.  Never had I experienced government forcing 
the public to save energy in such a spartan way.  Sure they have public 
announcements and TV ads asking the public yes.  

But never have I seen media trying to scare people by saying too much 
aircon will make you sick or leaving fan on while you sleep could kill you 
or saying vintage furnace with low heat during cold winter will toughen you 
up.  

It's a bullshit I'd say.
comments.author: Xentradi97

comments.text:

 Nah, that's pretty much the case everywhere. Companies matter more then

especially working class and poor.

top_comment.text:
Did you know that heavy air conditioning of the public spaces were illegal 
in South Korea? It sure is uncomfortable, but the government there is doing 
a great job for the environment. Don't compare that with Canada...... air 
conditioning here is just crazy.﻿
top_comment.author: Wandrative

comments.text:
+Eat Your Kimchi Hi:) Just wanted to tell you the eco-side of the story.
Yes it is illegal, at least in public buildings such as Walmart (or any 
other large shops, markets, and so on), office buildings, government 
buildings (city halls, schools, etc), all small shops (average grocery 
shops, bookstores, and so on), and venues (restaurants, libraries, and 
health centres like your gym, except saunas because well, I think you'd 
know why). During the summers, the temperature should not be 
cooled down to 25C (Or 27C or in between) and during the winters, it goes 
the other way around. Random checks will be made from 'ordinary 
looking' guys from the government by simply measuring the temperature 
inside the building. If the temperature is indeed exceeding (or cooler 
than) its limit, the facility owner will be heavily fined. It's not only 
South Korea, but many other countries are doing this (mostly European 
countries, and in fact, most people do not even own air conditioners in 
France). Since I'm just a random person on the internet, you can ask and 
talk about this with your Korean friends or co-workers. :)
comments.author: Wandrative

comments.text:
I'm confused as to how it's "illegal."  Does that mean that the police 
check your electricity bill, and if it's too high they come to your place 
and arrest you?
comments.author: Eat Your Kimchi

top_comment.author: Navi

comments.text:
+Navi

Basic economics for large multi-national agricultural corporations, the 
most striking example being "Monsanto." Monsanto is not only a producer of 
the base product (i.e. corn), they also have their hands throughout the 
entire line of production including the final product (i.e. pepto bismol). 
Therefore, it's to their benefit to make everything via one crop. If you 
have 100 acres of land, is it more efficient to have a 100 acres of corn, 
or 25/corn, 25/wheat, 25/barley, 25, etc... you get the point. Also, corn 
is incredibly durable, has a short maturation cycle, and is in general 
cheap and easy to make. 

So... going back, if you're making pepto bismol, and you can use corn syrup 
or some other derivative to introduce to pepto instead of a more expensive 
alternative, what would you use? Sugar(i.e. cane, brown, white, etc...)? 
Why use that on your pepsi's, when you have corn sugar which is a 1/10th of 
the cost? Hey, you like eating beef? Feed them corn, despite the fact that 
cows aren't naturally predisposed to eat corn, which many scientists 
suggest "corn" may actually be partially responsible for mad cow disease, 
etc...

TLDR? In short, it's super f'n cheap.
comments.author: kimjack1000

comments.text:
+kimjack1000 Someone told me about that after we came back, even stuff that 
has nothing to do with corn has it inside. He also told me the sugar in 
your coke and drinks is actually corn syrup? why not just use regular sugar 
like we do here? I don't get it. 
It didn't taste bad though, your coke tastes the same as ours. plus you 
guys have Cherry coke *O* sooo good. Wish we has that here.
comments.author: Navi

comments.text:
+L Sant Because eating out here, there are plenty of more healthy options. 
you always have great salad options which fill you up. 
Even when you buy a Shawarma (everywhere! haha), there is meat, but the 
fries portion is small, and you get lots of tiny plates to eat free salad, 
pickles and other veggies. When I was in the US we did try to order 
healthier meals, its not like we went to McDonald's everyday. but whenever 
we did order a salad - it was really bad and only had lettuce in it, and 
maybe chicken. when I asked for veggies with my pancake at morning 
breakfast I got weird looks from the waitress. and I got bacon on 
practically everything even when I didn't order it, even at morning 
breakfast XD whats up with that?
comments.author: Navi

Google it.

top_comment.text:
Running water at all times and drinkable tap water!
Wether it'd be hot or cold water, to always have access to that wasn't 
something I'd go and think about. Until I visited my family from my mothers 
side.
Whenever I'd go and be; like hmm I think I'm a little thirsty, I'd always 
have to ask my mom if we had any (chilled) water bottles and sometimes 
someone had forgotten to put them in the fridge so you'd have to drink 
lukewarm/warm water (not fun if it's 35+ Celsius in the shadow).
Or if you wanted to shower you'd have to see if the water was running (if 
we had run out of the stored water) and if it was you'd have to fill up 
this tank (which took forever) and then heat some of it up so you can mix 
the warm and cold water until it's the perfect temperature. Anyway it was 
always such a hassle, but now I know how much I appreciate the clean tap 
water here in Sweden!!﻿

captions.text: We're back Korea
We're back in the Nasty studio
And Simon and Martina from Korea ask:
What are the differences between Toronto and Seoul?
Can you talk about your experiences while you were in Toronto?
I mean, these aren't going to be like, you know...
EPIC MIND-BLOWING DIFFERENCES THAT YOU SHOULD WRITE DOWN
Or maybe you should.
These are just little things that you can observe if you've been from one country or another.
And this isn't trying to be any kind of like an angry fight-starter about like:
Canada is better than Korea. Korea is better than Canada.
Because that happened in our Korea vs Japan video
I'm pretty sure that happened in our Korea vs Australia video as well
Yeah, people were like Angry.
It seems like if there is a "vs" in there
the nationalistic pride swells up
and you have to start being racist and start yelling something
We're just trying to talk about the different things that we've observed
That's it.
I don't want to see that in the comments.
So settle down.
So stop frothing at the mouth.
Now let's start with something serious and important
Like going to the gym.
Very different in Canada than it is here.
Oh man, I miss the Canadian gyms.
I never thought I would say that.
Because I was never a gym goer in Canada.
I only went for...
I was going to say rehab...
That's not the right word.
Physiotherapy?
Physiotherapy
Yeah, you don't say "rehabbing my knee"
Because it was addicted to running.
I feel old and out of [S]*Cricket* *cricket* *cricket*
Ok. When we were in Toronto
We joined the "Good life", which is a chain of gyms
that are attached to supermarkets
And their gyms are about everywhere
Yeah, they are everywhere. And they are 24/7 some of them
We joined them for just two weeks.
And we were just blown away by the differences
First of all: they are huge.
There is so much equipment.
And there are like double machines of the same equipment
While in Korea in the gyms that we've gone to
There is a lot of equipment that's missing
Stuff that I'd like to be able to use, but just doesn't exist here
Well Korea has a lot of treadmills.
A lot of bikes and a lot of ellipticals. That's like their thing.
Well not a lot, well like, there are a lot more treadmills.
But the thing is also... The big difference that we noticed is:
In Canada, when people are at the gym, they really bust ass.
Like they're dripping sweat, they're on the treadmill running their asses off
They're are on the elliptical pumping it
While... here... people... walk really slowly.
We've discussed this before. It seems like there is this concern
amongst Korean people, that they are going to get beefy
If they work out too hard.
And I'm like... [S]Working out for two hours today at gym [M]Watching Korean dramas
Let me answer my phone. What ye doin? Oh, nothing...
Just at the gym. [S]Just walking, just working out.
It's kind of frustrating when you actually go there to push yourself.
But anyways, the point is that... [S]Because we go there and are like UGH THREE
UGH FOUR [M]Name five songs on your work-out playlist.
Go. Tyler the Creator's "ramba"? or"rumba"? [S]That's "Jamba"
El-P's "Up all night"
Wonder Girls "Like this"
2PM "A.D.T.O.Y."
Oh, that's such a good song to work out to.
Like haru jongil ni saenggak ppuniya ppuniya
Well I'm at like four and you haven't said anything yet. [S]RJD2 "temperamental"
Crystal Castles [S] Fucking buttons "brainfreeze"
That's a bad word!
This conversation is over.
Something else we really like about the gyms in Canada:
temperature control
Whoa, things you take for granted.
Like what... I took this for so... Ok.
In the summertime in Korea our gyms are like 35degree celcius.
Sweltering hot
There are a lot of air conditioners in our gym
They've got five of them in the ceiling
But they are just for display.
How pretty they are up there
We heard that it's good to work out in the heat
So that's good.
But now when we're in our gym and it's like 8*C and we literally can't pick up the dumbbells
Because it's so cold that our hands are freezing
I don't understand where this concept of working out in shitty conditions is good for you
You know what? It's also good to work out on the back of a hungry bear
Because if you survive, that makes you really strong. [M]Motivation, right?
Yes. That's garbage.
It's frustrating. Now that we've been to Canada and joined the gym
the temperature control: it's not too hot, it's not too cold
There's nothing blowing on you
You sweat but you're not cold. Your muscles aren't seizing.
Why can't we have that here?
Seems like this no temperature control thing happens all over Korea
For example, anyone who is attending high-school in Korea or is a teacher in Korea
Will know that you have a heater in a classroom
that is basically like a blow dryer
That is just blow drying you
But then when you go into the hallway, there is no heating.
So, the entire place is freezing, everyone is being like *shivers*
And then you rush into the classroom and you blast the heat because you are freezing.
And if you're too close to it, you roast; if you're too far from it, you freeze.
You've got to find somewhere in the middle
where you don't die.
I don't like that...
When we were in Canada, every mall we went to, every bus we were in,
Every time we were on the subway
In Korea you run into the subway and you peel off all of your clothes because you're dripping with sweat
within like 30 seconds.
And the subways are packed with people, so you don't even need heat,
because you people-heat
It's just that in Canada they know how to control the temperatures...
Ok, we've been ragging on Korea for a bit now.
Let's say something positive that we really love that we've noticed.
Ok, the thing that I really... [M]Lost your train of thought on?
What were you trying to do there, Simon?
I don't know [M]What were you trying to do Honey Bunny?
It's ok , just keep going.
People missed you and your strangeness.
I'm surry~
What were you trying to say?
What we really noticed about Korea is that things get built here very fast.
And taken care of as well.
While in Canada we noticed that there are a lot of roads that have a lot of holes in them
And cracks in them
And buildings are falling apart in a lot of places
And there is not a lot of new stuff being built from what we see
While in Korea things get done so fast.
Ok now, wait a second.
One thing we have to say is that we totally understand that there are different governments
Different tax payers dollars
different unions
Regulations and what not
Right, like Canadian people have to wear hard-hats.
And Korean people are like: I'm smoking and I'm using a blow torch
Which we actually saw
We saw it out of the window.
I know that the situations are different in each country
But just observing basically: things in Korea get built quickly and just all of the time.
Ok, now a simple example I want to say:
The sidewalks near our home
These are the cobblestone sidewalks which people installed
and every year the wintertime happens
And the flooding happens
And the bricks will kind of pop out
You know what I mean?
When there is a plant that always pops out and you're like "How did you get here?!"
In Korea there will be someone jumping on that right away
They'll dig up that hole, they'll re-cement it
And that's it. They just touch it up.
But there are places in Toronto, like we went to UOFT that we re-visited again
That have had cracks in the ground that I remember form way back when we were in school
That has only gotten bigger.
Well they are historical cracks
They have a lot of depth and history, and characterization
Uh... 200 students have rolled their ankles in this crack since then
